The section below Manjushri praised in the chapter on Cunda is the third, the praise by Manjushri.
There are four parts:

First, understanding and accomplishing his teachings; second, praising the correspondence between words and actions; third, praising the profound understanding of the Buddha's intent; fourth, accepting the exhortation. I say:

One should know that the ten rejections are spoken from the traces, and using the beginning of the small to challenge the end of the great is also afraid that the assembly at that time and future generations will only grasp the beginning of the small to challenge the end of the great, obstructing the use of the end of the great to destroy the beginning of the small.

Moreover, you exhort me to cover the conditioned, and I also exhort you to cover the unconditioned.

Although one speaks of existence all day long, one cannot exhaust its function; although one speaks of nonexistence all day long, one cannot reach its ultimate. Words cannot describe it, so it is set aside.
Moreover, set aside means to set aside the brief for the extensive, which is the world.
The true essence of nirvana is neither essence nor function, neither conditioned nor unconditioned.
Since it is not the true essence, it can be set aside together, which is the ultimate meaning of set aside.
You encourage me to cover existence, I encourage you to cover nonexistence, we argue back and forth, not knowing which is correct, which is the counteractive meaning of set aside.

The conditioned and unconditioned are secondary discussions. The main point here is to offer the food. Setting aside the secondary and returning to the main point is called setting aside for now, which is the meaning of set aside for the individual.

The text has four parts:

The first part is also twofold:

In encouraging offerings, there are three points:
First, encouraging in a timely manner, second, encouraging speed, third, encouraging to serve the Buddha.
Encouraging in a timely manner means like when first setting out, when first arriving, when sick, when things are newly ripe. Now the final offering is at the time of first departure.
Second, encouraging speed means that the ancient Buddha's way is not to eat after noon, so now quickly attend to this time.
Third, encouraging to serve the Buddha means precisely to make the final offering to the Buddha's nirvana.
Next, reprimanding Pure Gift also has three points:
First, not knowing the time, second, not knowing speed, third, not knowing the Buddha.
First, the one who makes the timely offering means that you encourage timely giving, the Buddha can accept timely giving, but all the great assembly is not in nirvana, this is not the time.
Asking for a non-timely offering involves greed in principle.
Next, not knowing speed means that the Buddha practiced austerities for six years, still eating only a little sesame and rice, so why be in such a hurry now?
Third, not knowing the Buddha means do you think the Tathagata really needs to eat?

Manjushri shares the view of others, thinking he needs to eat ordinary food, while Cunda expresses his understanding that eating is not eating, so he rebukes Manjushri for falling into the three kinds of unknowing.
Next, from at that time the Buddha told... the Tathagata affirms and praises to complete the previous and initiate the next.
Affirming the rebuke is to complete the previous, praising his wisdom is to initiate the next.
Third, from Manjushri told Cunda... this clarifies delight and approval.
There are five parts:
First, partial celebration and approval, second, refuting partial approval, third, approval in both aspects, fourth, approval through understanding, fifth, approval through complete detachment.
The assembly at the time thought Cunda's practice was shallow, so the Buddha affirmed what he approved to refute the feelings of the time.
First, MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« praises this biased [view] and says, What you say about the unconditioned delights the Buddha.
Next, Cunda uses the perfect to refute the biased, saying, It not only delights me, but also delights all.

Third, MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« sets up two rounds of arguments, first determining [the issue], saying, If it is determined to delight all sentient beings, then my talk of the conditioned should also delight [the Buddha].

If it does not delight my perfect [view], then the meaning of 'all' is refuted, and it is still not perfect, but biased delight, which would mean the Buddha has love and hatred, and so [MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«] sets up a counter-argument.
Fourth, Cunda realizes [MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«'s] counter-argument and resolves two issues:
First, there is no biased, tainted delight; second, there is universal, pure delight.
There are three points to the absence of bias:
First, he criticizes the absence of biased delight; second, he explains the meaning of the absence of bias; third, he uses an analogy to illustrate it, as in the text.

The meaning here clarifies that delight and non-delight are the realm of the Buddha, which cannot be measured, which is the delight and approval of cessation of thought.
First, the analogy clarifies that the wisdom of distinction does not reach the ultimate.

This text is still part of the Life Chapter in the Sanskrit version. Xie's division into two has ten differences:ğŸ”½The previous chapter is from the perspective of people, the later chapter is from the perspective of events;
The previous chapter is for the laity, this chapter is for the monastic;
The previous chapter has offerings, this chapter has no offerings;
The previous chapter has dual requests, this chapter has a single request;
The previous chapter is due to people, this chapter is on one's own initiative;
The previous chapter briefly clarifies the permanence of Buddha-nature, this chapter fully explains the three dots and four virtues;
The previous chapter discusses the present teaching, this chapter includes both present and past;
The previous chapter is a discussion between two people, this chapter is a discussion with the Buddha;
The previous chapter moves the grasping of the Dharma to give rise to doubt, this chapter destroys grasping and eliminates doubt;
In the previous chapter, hearing the Dharma was suppressed and cut off, in this chapter, seeing the earth move and lamenting.
However, these ten meanings are all inclusive and exclusive. Now, one side is raised to show its difference.
Xinghuang explained this chapter in seven ways, namely three requests, three rewards, and a conclusion.
It says that when the Buddha enters nirvana, sentient beings are helpless, so they lament and request him to stay in the world.
The Buddha responds, saying:

You originally offered alms and listened to the Dharma. Now you have received the alms and have given rise to your blessings and virtues. I have already explained the new teaching, which has given rise to your wisdom. But you are unwilling to learn. Knowing that staying [in the world] is of no benefit, what is the use?
Next, the request is like the TathÄgata's teaching of impermanence in the past, which was only accomplished after fifty years;

Now, teaching the new teaching of permanence, bliss, self, and purity, he should stay in the world for a long time to teach and instruct. If he enters nirvana, it is no different from practicing the old teaching again.
Citing the elephant's footprints and autumn plowing, he is reluctant to accept the teaching.
The Buddha then responds, saying:

It is not that he does not teach at all, but he will eventually cause you to attain the new character of the perfect interfusion of the three truths. Therefore, it says, I will place all the children in the secret treasury, and I will also abide in it, called entering nirvana.
Previously, they pitifully prayed, but since he did not allow them to abide, they should only chide and exhort him to make a request.
If the TathÄgata possesses permanence, bliss, self, and purity, then he avoids the four inverted views and gains mastery, abiding in the world for a long time.
If he definitely enters nirvana, then he does not avoid the inverted views, and the words permanence and bliss are in vain.
If he does not abide, then our poisonous bodies cannot endure for long, and we will also enter nirvana together with the Buddha.
The Buddha then replied:

How can you know my coming and going? You say that coming is definite coming and abiding is definite abiding, but my coming and going is like two birds flying together. Coming is always abiding, so why bother to request abiding?
Abiding is always coming, so why need to request?
If you do not understand this, how can you attain the same nirvana as me?
Having three times requested without success, his mind was confused and he gave rise to doubt:
If impermanence is not true, it should not have been taught in the past;
If permanence, bliss, self, and purity are true, why was it not taught earlier?
The TathÄgata would then have the fault of not adapting to capacities.
The Buddha then explained:ğŸ”½In the past, I taught impermanence to eliminate your illness of permanence;
Now, since you have become ill with impermanence, I teach you permanence.
Your illness has a sequence, so the teachings have their rise and fall.
You arbitrarily think that the teaching is given too early or too late, but the TathÄgata bends and follows you. How can the Buddha's adapting to capacities be early or late?
You yourself blame the TathÄgata.
The arising of this kind of thought is easy to understand.
Moreover, the three requests come first, and the three responses come later. The sub-sections in between are related to each other everywhere.
This is the profound discussion of the seven meanings by that teacher. If one wants to explain it, it is far from the arising of the meaning.
Now, it is explained that this chapter is for the sake of the bhiká¹£us, bestowing the new and perfect teaching, which surpasses the three cultivations.
The text is divided into four parts:
1. The great assembly's request, 2. The Tathagata's response, 3. The bhikshus' doubts and attachments, 4. The Buddha's removal of doubts.
The request is also divided into two parts:

The conditions refer to the earth shaking, knowing that [the Buddha] will definitely enter nirvana, and therefore requesting with sadness.
Question:
Who shook the earth as a condition?
Answer:

The Dharma is neither in causes nor in conditions, neither in causes and conditions nor apart from causes and conditions. Since [the Dharma] arises from causes and conditions, how can there be an agent?
Although there is no agent, it is also the Buddha's spiritual powers that shake the earth, causing [sentient beings] to feel sad and place those with conditions in liberation.
It is also the Buddha's wisdom power to expound the Dharma, joyfully placing those with conditions in prajna.
It is also the Buddha's power of essence, neither sad nor joyful, placing those with conditions in the Dharma body.
It is also the power of Sudana and Manjushri's wisdom, causing the assembly to understand and enter prajna.
Also, when the two people used their spiritual powers to leave, the earth shook, causing the assembly to feel grief and enter into liberation.
It is also the power of the ultimate truth of the two people, causing the assembly to enter the Dharma body without sorrow or joy.

It is also the power of the assembly to feel the antidote, hearing the Dharma with joy and feeling the power of the people.ğŸ”½The shaking of the earth is not out of sorrow, but out of feeling the ultimate truth;
Without sorrow or joy, it causes the earth to shake.
Its meaning is immeasurable.
The VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a SÅ«tra says, Some are afraid, some are joyful, some give rise to disgust, and some resolve their doubts. This is the unique spiritual power.
There are four aspects to the shaking of the earth: time, place, characteristics, and cause.

As for time, the Buddha used four things to stop the grief of Kapilavastu. Cunda's chest and abdomen slightly awakened, he lowered his head and drank tears, and the great assembly temporarily stopped grieving upon hearing the Dharma.
After the two people left and the Dharma sound ceased, wanting to increase their good thoughts of longing and affection, not long after they left, at that time,
the earth shook, which was the time.
As for the location, the great earth is the horizontal location, and the Brahma world is the vertical location.

Some say the first dhyana is the Brahma world, or that the four dhyanas are all the Brahma world. Although not connected to the earth, there are jeweled palaces that also shake, which is the matter at hand.
Question:
Above, it is explained that the sound and light reach up to the peak of existence, but now this earthquake only reaches the Brahma palace?
Answer:
Above, it says the peak of existence, and the text on the peak of existence is broad, so it can be understood as far-reaching;
Here, it says the Brahma world, which is just the text.

If according to the text below, When shaking, it can cause the minds of sentient beings to shake, called the great earth shaking, the four minds of the formless realm should also be shaken, which is the example.
As for the characteristics, there are three:
First, the small and great movement characteristics, second, the six kinds of movement characteristics, and third, the thirty-eight movement characteristics.
These three kinds of characteristics all take form and sound as their basis. Form has movement, surging, and rising, while sound has shaking, awakening, and roaring.
If there is only form or sound, it is called a small movement. Form and sound moving together is called a great movement.
Form and sound each having three is called the six kinds. One more three in one is called movement, universal movement, and equal universal movement. Three sixes are eighteen.

If further distinguished, JambudvÄ«pa, one four-continent world system, a small chiliocosm, a medium chiliocosm, a trichiliocosm, and the ten directions, are compared one by one to make small, great, and greatly great movements.
Some people say:
This sÅ«tra has six kinds, while the Huayan has eighteen movements.
How could this be so?
It is simply that in form, only one movement is mentioned, and in sound, only one shaking is mentioned.

It is also said to be greatly shaken, and it is also said to be able to shake the minds of sentient beings. One should know that the meaning includes the eighteen [earth-tremors], which is different from human feelings.
Due to this, it should be known that there are also small due to, great due to, and greatly great due to.

If a wheel-turning king is born or passes away, the earth grieves when it loses its ruler and rejoices when it gains a ruler, so it shakes. This is called a small shaking.ğŸ”½If a pratyekabuddha or arhat is born or passes away, the earth grieves when it loses its worthy of offerings and rejoices when it gains a worthy of offerings, so it shakes. If a Buddha is born or passes away, the earth spirits, mountain spirits, and various devas, nagas, etc. grieve when they lose their worthy of offerings and rejoice when they gain a worthy of offerings, so it shakes. This is called a greatly great shaking.
The present sutra clearly explains the eight appearances of the Tathagata, only lacking ascending to heaven and subduing Mara. The text is abbreviated and does not include them.

Next, the two lines like the sun at first rising use the two analogies of the sun and the mountain to pray and request, praising the one Buddha who possesses three benefits.
The sun has three meanings:

First, the high, round, and bright analogy of the benefit of the ruler, giving birth to and nurturing myriad things is the analogy of the benefit of the relative, illuminating and dispelling darkness is the analogy of the benefit of the teacher.
But the analogy text discusses illumination, and the combined text clarifies dispelling darkness, which correctly states that the meaning of the teacher is the basis, and it also has two abilities.

The mountain also has three meanings: being high above the water illustrates the benefit of being the master, penetrating deep into the water illustrates the benefit of being close, and the color of the water being the same as the mountain illustrates the benefit of being the teacher.

The virtue of the teacher is like a mountain, peacefully dwelling in the ocean of the assembly, able to proclaim the wonderful wisdom to illuminate the darkness and confusion below, the words are brief but the meaning is comprehensive.
The old explanations say that the sun illuminates itself, but the arguments are not the same.
Kaishan and Zhuangyan say:
The Buddha has wisdom that can illuminate himself.
Guangzhai says:
The fruition of Buddhahood does not have the wisdom of self-reflection.
Guanshi (Guan Shi) criticizes Guangzhai, saying:
If the Buddha does not have the wisdom of self-reflection, he should not know whether he has become a Buddha or not.
They rescue by saying:
Although the Buddha does not have wisdom, he knows whether he has become a Buddha or not.
If he wants to know, he borrows the wisdom of other Buddhas, because the way of the Buddhas is the same.
Now I ask further:
Since the way of the Buddhas is the same, and other Buddhas do not have wisdom, what can be borrowed?
Moreover, if it can only know others' lack of wisdom and know itself, it should only be able to awaken others, not be called self-awakened.
This is Guangzhai's four errors, separating the true from the mundane, purifying the land with cow dung, and pointing to the tip of the finger as the unborn and neutral Tathagata.
Next, he asks Kaishan and Zhuangyan:
If you use the wisdom of counter-illumination to illuminate the wisdom of all aspects, which wisdom do you use to illuminate the wisdom of counter-illumination?
This would be endless.
The Guan master himself says:
